author: A_Brickset_user
title: A perfect set for being re-released
review:
I just got it, attached it to Black Falcon's Fortress (I removed the Crusader Knights, made them a two man wondering knights troupe, and turned the Falcon Knight into an archer.), had some fun (+ some trouble with some incredibly weak spiral staircases of my own making), and it looks great. I hope to get a second, so I can build it up to make a good sized inn. The innkeeper is more like nobility than an innkeeper, so I removed the headware cone, and the cape, and gave her a ponytail hairpiece. The headware bit came in handy finishing off the queen of my Castleworld. I seriously recommend this set to all LEGO fans, it's great! Why was my box all black and white, with clouds on the back instead of alternate building ideas??????? The second set this year that actually offered me a challenge to build. The first was my Black Falcon's Fortress.

NOTE: I have the re-released version, not this exact one. But the pieces are the same.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: A true classic!
review: This is one of the best castle sets ever made! I bought mine a couple of years ago for only 75 NOK!(About 11 $) And I'm a very happy owner. This set contains four cool figures and thebox is very cool. I wish Lego kept producing the legend version, but why did they give it a new number? But this set is awesome even in a "modern" town.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Good inn
review: It is a wonderfull set with 1 knight 2 soldiers an innkeepster and a horse.It has great castle wall pieces in black and red and Blue flowers, a novelty in 1986. it has also a little attick and 2 goblets and a cooking pan.

author: StormSworder
title: Ah, happy memories
review: This has to be on the shortlist of best sets Lego have ever made, shows what a shame it is that there weren't more civilian Castle sets.  The tavern itself is a wonderfully-designed building, fabulously detailed and containing enough useful pieces for endless alternative building.  A set which genuinely deserves its classic status.

author: Novelty
title: A European House!
review:
Yes, there's a wall in this set which can be connected to the rest of the castle sets with walls, but this set is more than the wall!  This set actually has a little house that's setup as a tavern.  Granted there isn't much inside - no beds, only a big table and two bricks that can be used as pretend stools... but there is a fireplace and there is a sheltered part that can be used as a stable for the horse.

This set is atypical in a few other ways - it is one of the first to include Lego flowers, for example, and the only one with red corner/45º walls and of course, one of the few sets with a female minifig.  This set is great in so many ways that when they were looking for a set to include in Legends, they picked this one out of the many Castle sets.

author: Ernst
title: Guarded Inn, the civilian's Castle !!
review:
Overall 5 bricks: One of the best ever Castle sets, the predecessor of great sets as The Medieval Market Village and The Mill Village Raid. Beautyfull detailed, great accesoires, sufficient minifigures, great to built and these days hard to get. It offers the Inn with interior, a small tower and a guarded pass through that als can be used to stall the horses of the guests.

 

Building 5 bricks: building is great fun with all kinds of parts like the usual Castle wall plates, the small grey bricks, some bows to attach the wall to the Inn. Nothing really difficult but you have to keep paying attention. The front of the Inn is attached with hinges so you can open it, looks and works great. The roof is all made with black slopes with a tiny yellow window in it, great detail ! On the top of the roof a small tower to guard the Inn, also nice designed. On the frontside of the Inn also a chimney, nothing is forgotten.

 

Parts 5 bricks: Brilliant colour setting, the red wall parts are marvelous just like the blue door and the 2 small yellow shutters. Wonderfull minifigures being the two Crusader Knights and the visiting horseman (probably a Black Falcon Knight in peacetime). The best figure of course being the female Inn keeper. Also great are the small accesoires such as the goblet, the frying pan, the flowers and the unique Black Flag. Sufficient weapons for the guarding knights present too.

 

Playabilty 5 bricks: what can I say, just look at it. No words needed I think.

 

Value 5 bricks: Last known new price is not valid anymore, Bricklink offers an average of â‚¬ 65,00 for this set. For a brilliant set like this worth every cent I think, it will only increase the coming years I think.

author: Arrvilohr
title: What a gem of a Castle set this is...!
review:
What an absolute wonderful set this is!! This tavern makes the Lego castle world so much richer. There were only a few sets which did not focus on the battle experience of the Middle Ages and this is the most important one.

The set is (near to) flawless. I can't think of something which bothers me really, except maybe that the inside of the Inn is not really big. On the other hand, lot's of positive things to say about it:

° It contains a piece of wall which can connect to other Castle sets from those years. If you have some of these sets, you can make a very nice walled medieval village. This is a very clever feature.

° Some nice details are included: I like the small part on the roof where the archers can guard the inn. The chimney is cool too. They did not forget about the cups to drink from! The flowers make the place cosy. 

° Next to the standard Castle grey parts, some great colorful parts are included. It establishes the great look of the finished set.

° Four minifigs is just right for the set. The female one serves perfect as the hostess. By the way: the legs of the minifig on the wall (on the picture on the box) are not correct. Inside the box you get the black legs twice, for both soldiers.

° Lots of playability: as the front wall can be opened, it is a lot easier to reach inside the Inn. Not much fantasy required to come up with dozens of stories to play.

I think it's clear from my review I am a big fan of this set. I remember being a child an looking at it in the Lego catalogue for the hundredth time. I never got it as a child, but bought it as an adult after my dark ages. If you can find it for a reasonable price, don't hesitate, you won't regret it, certainly if you are a Castle fan!

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
This is possibly one of the most beautiful LEGO sets from this era, it is the only true civilian building and the sign and red structural elements are only included within this model, apparently this was also one of the first sets with flowers.

 It was seen as such a good set that it was also released as a Legends again in 2001; it was also nice to see the Falcons and Crusaders united in peace over the common good of alcohol.

If you like this review click on the link to find it and all reviews of the Castle sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/08/lego-castle-crusaders-sets-1984-1992.html

author: goldenbane
title: Spend a night at the original Lego Medieval Inn!
review: I believe I acquired this set when Lego re-released it some years ago.  I thought it was a very nice set, and could imagine a lot of kids having a blast playing with it.  It's honestly a little bigger than what I originally thought it was, so that was a surprise.  It connects with other castles of that time period, allowing you to create one humongous super castle!  Loads of play value here.

author: mediAFOL
title: Should be a mess, but somehow it works
review:
There is a lot of love for the Guarded Inn. It seemed incredibly popular for a medium-sized set, and for some time, I confess to having been a tad nonplussed by the admiration. However, it piqued my curiosity enough for me to find a near-complete set.

I'm won over. The gorgeous colour of the red half-timbered Inn seems to grow like foliage out of the grey walls of the fortification. I love that someone came up with the whole concept, as it feels unique, and not just within the Lego world.

Although I'm no fan of prefab wall pieces, there is no denying how pretty the red half-timbered panels are. One could make a similar bright red building out of plain red bricks, but it would look too childish, perhaps like a junior barn model. The hinged front wall pleasingly pays homage to the earlier hinged yellow Castle, while also prefiguring the fabulous hinged buildings in the later Medieval Market Village.

There's a kind of joy at the commitment to the bizarre concept of the whole model. "Guarded Inns have towers, right?". Throw in the hennin-clad hostess figure, and you do indeed have a perfect smaller classic castle set.
